comments.text:
Esta película es una de mis favoritas de este género, GRABOID o TREMORS o 
TERROR BAJO LA TIERRA o TEMBLORES, así es como muchos la conocen, no hay 
mucho que decir más que te entretiene por más de una hora esperando a 
cuándo saldrán otra vez de la tierra y quién será el próximo al que 
comerán. 

Un monstruo subterráneo, agresivo, hermafrodita y ciego que se guía solo 
por el sonido procedente de la superficie y las vibraciones, esta cazando a 
un diminuto poblado, dos inseparables amigos deciden ir a conseguir ayuda 
fuera del poblado, sin embargo, el único camino que los llevaría hacia la 
carretera ha sido bloqueado, con miedo y frustrados, deciden regresar con 
los demás, y unirse junto a una sismóloga a luchar por su vida sobre este 
ser que no está solo.

Billy Jang 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qFNBUs7O-h4﻿

comments.text: wow the image quality is great for a film of the time﻿
comments.author: Stew782

comments.text:
+degree7 Ya I agree man. I honestly have no idea why I said that! Because 
im one of those people that prefers film over digital (just like I prefer 
practical over CGI effects)... I mustve been tired or drunk when I made 
that comment lol ;)
And I agree 100% that it looks better. Digital looks 'sharp' or something? 
Cant put the right word on it. Film just looks better. Im glad certain 
directors are trying to keep it, like Quentin Tarantino. He is filming his 
new movie, the Hateful Eight, in 70mm. Which I believe is the same that 
Lawrence of Arabia was filmed in! The super wide screen film captures 
cinematography better imo.
Anyway, my original comment wasnt meant to discuss the merits of film vs 
digital, just trying to understand what the OP meant by 'image quality is 
great for a film of its time' (which I still dont understand what he means 
by that).... I think I couldve worded it a bit better, sorry ;)
comments.author: sergeantbigmac

comments.text:
+sergeantbigmac Pssh, no way is digital better. Film stock will always look 
better when shot in natural light, and the grain and dreamlike quality adds 
to the cinematic experience of it. Film actually mimics the human eye 
better than digital, which is why digital often looks so aesthetically 
unpleasing.
comments.author: degree7

comments.text:
What do you mean image quality? Digital film is better, but old school 
celluloid film still had excellent resolution. IDk what they were using 
back then, probably 60mm since its a big budget film.
comments.author: sergeantbigmac

comments.author: Hatted Sandwich

comments.text:
+jw870206 precisely! Why do directors make action scenes completely out of 
CGI and try to convince everyone that it's better than an actual set. Star 
Wars Episode III is a good example of how some amazing CGI can get over 
used and make scenes feel fake; the actors ability to act is also taken 
down a notch because they don't really understand the situation or 
environment they are in, since all they see is green screen.
comments.author: Marcus Siebert

comments.text:
You have to employ CGI in a properly synchronized manner to make it 
convincing. They combined CGI and stop motion for instance, in Terminator 2 
to produce the T-1000.
comments.author: SueMorphPlus2009

comments.text:
+jw870206 That's actually a very good example of how the two work together 
if done well.
comments.author: Shaun Fontaine

comments.text:
CGI when done properly and usually alongside practical effects can be very 
effective and realistic. Jurassic Park, for instance, the CGI and practical 
are seamlessly edited together.
comments.author: jw870206

comments.text: Agreed, and I work in CGI.

comments.author: Mike Bee

comments.text:
+Jeremy Kegley
No it actually is an 8-gauge shotgun, the production used it to proxy a 
big-bore Elephant rifle, since many of them (like those made by H&H etc) 
are so freaking expensive the production doesn't want to be responsible for 
them. 
http://www.longmountain.com/just-for-fun/movie-guns/Tremors/ (Site even has 
the serial number of the correct gun)

Especially poignant since they dropped the gun during shooting and broke 
the stock.  From what I've read in the past, most of the guns seen in the 
'Tremors' movie franchise belonged to people working on the movie who 
loaned them to the production.
comments.author: VonArgylle

comments.text:

shotgun!
comments.author: Jeremy Kegley

comments.text: Type in 700 Nitro Express here on YouTube. Thats shows a nice vid of it.
comments.author: The Rebel 22

comments.text:
That would be Belgian-made William Moore & Co. 8 gauge shotgun. Little 
warning though if you actually can find one of those howitsers: DONT shoot 
it like Burt did (stock not supported by the shoulder) as in real life the 
recoil would have flung the gun upwards and given him a bad case of broken 
skull. And the ammo he loaded in the gun was solid slugs used to hunt 
elephants.

comments.author: Shanethefilmmaker

comments.text:
Highly unlikely to have been the first time those effects were attempted; 
more likely to be building on previous, smaller-scale work. A good team 
creates good effects, whatever the current tech level. That's why you get 
good and bad CG (and practical) today. There are advantages and 
disadvantages to both.
comments.author: DaveDexterMusic

comments.text:
Yes I believe the real one said "The right to bear arms on the grounds that 
Giant Underground Dwelling Maneating Worm Monsters will attack your 
basement." Because no one would believe that the U.S. Government would 
become a police state or that England will wanna take back the country.
comments.author: Shanethefilmmaker

comments.text:
The Thing and Tron. The Thing for Practical and Tron for CGI. That's my 
answer to your no Golden Age Remark. In Tron yes the effects would be 
laughable, but back then it was the first time they did something like that 
and while the movie was a flop it was vindicated by history. The Thing 
proved that with the right setup your monsters could look as real as 
animals are.
comments.author: Shanethefilmmaker

comments.text: funny how in the movie poster (JAWS style), the creature has many teeth.
comments.author: SuperErmacX

comments.text:
I'm going to blame most of Star Wars on Lucas being a shitty director. Some 
of the entirely CG scenes (the space battles, mainly) are breathtaking. 
These days there's no excuse for poorly executed CG (and plenty of howling 
shit) but, say . . . Real Steel. Or Pacific Rim. Fuck ME. And there's 
plenty of practical effects that were and are laughable as well; there was 
no golden age, just people who cared and got the most out of the tech 
available. At least . . . that's MY thinks :)
